ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Javier
Javier Fernandez Vega
Javier Fernandez Vega
Javier Fernandez-Vega
Javier Fernandez Vega
Javi Fernandez-Vega

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This class was interesting because it centered so much around the field trip to the Basque Country of Spain. That was the core of the course and all the work before and after the trip revolved around preparing for, analyzing, and synthesizing data for the field trip. So it wasn't exactly like a normal FES class. It was hard and times, and easy at times.

One of the best classes at FES. Very hands-on learning with the trip component, and we tackled real world problems. Ashton is such a great professor too, and it is very evident that he cares about the students learning a lot.
The professors good nature and keen interest and belief in our capabilities. Also the support and peer learning that takes place.

Mark is a great professor. He has a way with students, he's a really fun and good teacher, and he loves what he does it seems. The trip was excellent despite the trials and tribulations of international travel with a large group.
See question 11 (the trip and the prof! Also, small class size made it quite intimate and easy to get to know the other students).

The professor and TA selected a well rounded and dedicated group of people for the task/class - it was a crucial part of an excellent course to have a diverse groups of experiences and confidence in fields among the 9 members.

This was one of the most useful courses I have taken because of its practical applications. It was extremely beneficial to go through the exercises of preparing for a rapid assessment as part of a team, and Mark has done this so many times that he was able to provide clear leadership where needed and give us freedom where that was useful. It has been very interesting to see the process, group dynamics and product all develop before, during and after the trip.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The course is an advanced seminar course and largely relies on having the students teach other with Mark as a guide. Mark is an excellent guide but I would have liked to have seen how this technique of rapid assessments plays out in the real world more. Perhaps invite in a guest speaker or two to see how other people approach the process - in the end, without anything other than the professors word I am still left wondering how useful the process is, how economically and environmentally viable it is to fly eleven people from connecticut to spain) and how I would incorporate it into future work (or create work from this newly developed skill).
Can't think of anything.

It would be great to finish up work before the end of the semester rather than having the paper drag on after the break, but it's also nice to have the extra time to do a good job on the paper... not sure how to resolve this tension!

Administration and sharing of reference materials was somewhat problematic for this collaborative and fast-paced project. Perhaps setting up a framework of folders on a simple FTP site before the semester is under way would help this issue (a detail, but one that is time consuming to tackle during the course of the semester)

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA was excellent as an organizer for the course.
Both the TA and professor were always available and helpful, via e-mail, in person, etc. They operated as a well-oiled machine.
Instructor and TA availability was good.
Ashton was always available for help, and Javi was as well.
Excellent - both Mark and Javi were very responsive. Javi was particularly helpful on the field trip.

Mark and Javi were very helpful and gave great guidance. Tamara was an excellent in-country host and made herself very available in terms of time and energy throughout the entire course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: The course made me delve into the literature on a subject that I have interest in and was useful as a means of expanding my knowledge. The course was also very useful for improving my field assessment techniques.

I think it is a great capstone course that asks you to take all your other courses (social science, natural science, law, finance, etc) and apply them to thinking about a real case where there is no perfect solution and you have to use all your skills and knowledge together to quickly analyze, interpret, synthesize and report on a natural resource/forest management problem.
Quite well.

very useful- Provided me with a solid foundation on how to collaborate with a multidisciplinary team, conduct rapid appraisals using different social science techniques, and adapt to a client's requests while still maintaining objectivity.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The professorsexcellent reputation, course description, and my interest in working in smaller groups with academically motivated students.
To see how project developers, NGOs, decision-makers, etc. use inter-disciplinary approaches to quickly assess and propose actions in land management, conservation, stewardship plans.
Applicable, small class size, great instructor, trip to Spain.

Quickly and thoroughly gaining an understanding of protected areas management in a non-US context extended my professional skill set and gave me a chance to learn in-depth about the resources and challenges in this location. It was also an opportunity to work closely with my peers.
For the experience in would provide me, which I believe will be a useful tool in future research and consulting work.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes!
Yes. I enjoyed the course, learned a lot and felt like it was a good second-year course to take to tie together the past year and a half of coursework.
Yes
Yes
Yes
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I think it will be a class that I will look back on years from now and appreciate more than while in the thick of it. I wish I was leaving with more concrete "Tools" "skills" or "resources".
Yes
Yes
yes
Yes, and more so.
Yes, and I am enjoying the process of revisions now as we are working on papers

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The class was essentially a rapid assessments team. We all carried out individual pieces of the larger research and assessment mission, but collaborated continuously on the project. The disadvantages are just dealing with lots of unique personalities and channeling them effectively into one project.
The whole class worked as a group which was a very positive experience.
Very loosely though.
Our interests and interpretations of the topic were somewhat different; however, I feel this made our product stronger.

Self-segregating into teams by interest split up the group into personality combinations that probably wouldn't have happened otherwise, which was useful and informative. I enjoy the collaborative process of writing with a peer very much and it is much better motivation than deadlines to keep things moving.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take good notes in the field!

Stay on top of your research and reading of your topic areas and start writing early, even if you have to go back and rewrite. Just start thinking about what you want to get out of the class and what aspect of the project you want to tackle to meet your personal goals.

This was my favorite course I've taken so far at FES and I feel that I've learned the most as well. The structure the course was perfect for learning a great deal and limiting the size to 8 is about right (no more for sure). The key to class is being ready to work alot independently and who the other students are with you in the class. Having good classmates is essential as I learned as much from them as from the course itself. The course is alot of work so be ready for it.
Go with the flow! Enjoy the trip and make the most of the opportunity to learn from locals while there.

Do the preliminary work to understand your field site - it was immensely helpfulWork toward familiarity with all the topics your team will coverandDo not take this course because you want to go on a field trip
Get ahead in your other classes at the beginning of the semester- a 10 day field trip is a lot to catch up from.
